description: Dive into "Castles of Istanbul: A Journey Through Time" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Castles of Istanbul: A Journey Through Time

places.generalDescription: Anadoluhisarƒ±, a remarkable fortress perched on the Asian side of Istanbul, stands proudly at the narrowest point of the Bosphorus. Constructed in 1393 by Sultan Yildirim Bayezit, this historical gem was built atop ancient ruins once dedicated to Zeus. While it may be smaller than its European counterpart, Rumelihisari, Anadoluhisarƒ± boasts impressive towers reaching about 82 feet high and thick walls that tell tales of its storied past.

sources.snippet: The fortress is located on the Asian side of the Istanbul (Beykoz) at the narrowest point of the Bosphorous, a 14th century castle from the Ottoman‚Äôs first attempt to capture Istanbul will take you to an amazing experience. The fortress was built in 1395 on the ruins of an old temple dedicated to Zeus by the Sultan Yildirim Bayezit, and is made up of a citadel and its exterior walls, after the conquest of Istanbul it lost much of its strategic importance and was converted into a military hospital, the fortress is smaller in size when you compare to Rumeli Hisari on the European side. Its towers are about 82 feet high (25 meters) with a thickness of 7-16 feet (around 2-5 meters).
sources.shortName: Castles in Istanbul - Strongholds of History

sources.snippet: A 14th century relic of the Ottoman Empire's first attempt to conquer Istanbul, Anatolian Fortress is located on the Asian shore of Istanbul at the narrowest point of the Bosphorus strait. The Sultan Yildirim Bayezit built this fortress in 1393 on the ruins of a Byzantine temple dedicated to Zeus. It's much smaller in size when you compare with Rumelihisari fortress lying on the European side, just on the opposite.

The Anadolu Hisarƒ± is a medieval fortress located on the Asian side of the Bosphorus in Istanbul, Turkey. Built between 1393 and 1394 on the orders of Sultan Bayezid I, it was part of the preparations for the siege of Constantinople. The fortress served primarily as surveillance and control of maritime traffic on the Bosphorus.

places.name: Anadoluhisarƒ±

reviews.text: Beautifully restored. You need to be able to climb lots of steps.

Worth visiting, but paying to enter as a foreigner? Probably not. It cost me 450TL (July 2025) - the view was nice but it wasn't worth the price as there isn't that much historical information and the grounds are not big at all. I'd say, come, walk around, but don't pay

This is a very beautiful fortress. It is well restored, renovated and maintained. It is not as big as the other opposite fortress on the other side of the Bosphorus. The entrance is with a fee. You will get amazing views of the surrounding areas and the nearby creek from top of the walls and towers.

places.generalDescription: Rumeli Fortress, a 15th-century hilltop stronghold with numerous towers and scenic walking paths offering stunning views of the water, is a significant historical site in Istanbul. Situated on the European side of the Bosporus, it was constructed to safeguard the strait before the conquest. The fortress covers 30 acres and features towers named after supervisors during its construction.

sources.snippet: Rumeli Hisari was built by the Sultan Mehmet the Conqueror in just four months and directly on the opposite side to Anadolu Hisari in 1452 in preparation for the final attack on Constantinople which led to the downfall of the Byzantine Empire. It is located on the European side of the Bosphorous and in the northernmost district of Istanbul. Set within the lower part of the recently built Bosphorous University Campus, in a city where there is so much love and magic to discover.
sources.shortName: Castles in Istanbul - Strongholds of History

sources.snippet: Rumeli fortress was built by the sultan Mehmet the Conqueror in four months only and directly opposite to Anadoluhisari in 1452 in preparation for the final attack on Constantinople, which led to the downfall of the Byzantine Empire. The fortress is located at the narrowest section of the Bosphorus Strait (about 600 meters - 1970 feet). It occupies an area of 60.000 m2 (16 acres), had 4 main and 1 smaller gate, and 3 large and 1 smaller tower.

Rumeli Fortress (Rumeli Hisari) Recommended Tues-Sun 9am-5pm Tarabya Yenik√∂y Cad. north of Sariyer Transportation some ferries make the stop at Rumeli Kavagi; otherwise, get off at Sariyer and take a dolmus the rest of the way. By car, follow the shore road north from Dolmabah√ße Palace (there is no dolmus service from Taksim) through Besiktas, Ortak√∂y, Arnavutk√∂y, Bebek, and finally to Rumeli Hisari (the road changes names frequently)

places.name: Rumeli Fortress

reviews.text: Beautiful site. Was being restored when we visited so could only walk around the garden. But for 6 Euros it was a great place to be in a bit of nature and escape the busy city.

At about 6 euro entry, but also included with the muze card, it's a realistic price for a site like this.
However, the whole fortress is being restored, so you can not access any part of the walls , towers, and Ramparts.
So, while the conservation works are ongoing, I wouldn't bother coming here.
When open fully, I would definitely return. As of now, you'll spend more time getting there from the city centre than actually being there

Awesome views. If you're a local or student, very cheap, only 50 lira for students as of August 2025. Beautiful, breathtaking views. Can't walk on the walls for now because of renovations but most of the castle is visitable. There's also Ottoman and Byzantine artifacts on display in the fortress grounds.

Very underrated spot also, not many tourists here, mainly locals. Worth coming by via ferry.

places.address: Rumeli Hisarƒ±, Yahya Kemal Cd. No: 42, 34470 Sarƒ±yer/ƒ∞stanbul, T√ºrkiye

places.generalDescription: Partly restored Ottoman-era stone fort built into a cliff, overlooking the strait from arched walls.

sources.snippet: Rumelifeneri Castle is a historic fortress located on the Black Sea coast, in the Sarƒ±yer district, Istanbul, Turkey. Built in the 15th century by the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II, it was part of the fortifications for the siege of Constantinople in 1453 and controlled maritime traffic on the Bosphorus. The castle has been restored on several occasions, especially during the 20th century.

Rumeli Feneri Castle was built perfectly in the 18th century by a Greek architect on the north side of Istanbul, which is generally known as the region where the Greeks were located. The castle is a lighthouse built to monitor the entrance of French and British ships into the strait during the Crimean War.

places.name: Rumeli Feneri Castle

reviews.text: It's a good place for a picnic (please try to bring your plastic bag for your garbage). It has beautiful views of the Black Sea. It has a castle that it's not well preserved. For kids, just be careful with the cliff. Also, it has a parking lot.

The castle was closed it's not open for public, the view was amazing , it's far from city you need to go buy car, there is public transportation but it will take too much time , I believe the best time for visit and  enjoining nature is in spring or autumn

I have to say that I was surprised with this place..!
You can have a nice sea view time, I could sit there for hours calmly.
It's quite far and you will need a car, or you may use public transport, but a bus would take a long time.
Take your tea, sit on the rocks and enjoy the scenery and count the ships entering from the Black Sea into the Bosphorus.

places.generalDescription: Yoros Castle, also known as Genoese Castle, is a historic fortress located on the Anatolian side of the Bosphorus in Istanbul. Offering panoramic views of the Black Sea and the Bosphorus, this Byzantine-era ruin is a popular tourist attraction. Despite its deteriorating condition, it continues to draw visitors due to its historical significance and stunning scenery.

sources.snippet: Yoros Castle (Yoros Kalesi) is a historic fortress in the Beykoz district, on the Asian side of the Bosphorus, near Anadolu Kavaƒüƒ±, in Istanbul, Turkey. Originally built by the Byzantines in the 10th century, it was captured and rebuilt by the Genoese in the 14th century to control maritime traffic. In 1399, it was captured by the Ottoman Empire and became a strategic fortress.

Yoros Castle in the Asian side of Istanbul might be exactly what you are looking for. This hidden treasure gives insight into rich history of Turkey with some of the most amazing sceneries in this region. Therefore, if you are thinking about your next trip to Turkey or just dreaming about it, Yoros Castle must be at the top of your list.
sources.siteName: Guided Istanbul Tours - Ranked #1 on Tripadvisor
sources.shortName: Yoros Castle: A Hidden Gem in Turkey and Istanbul

sources.snippet: The castle was presumably built for the first time in the late 13th century by Byzantine Emperor Michael VIII Palaiologos. A now-defunct castle at Rumeli Kava on the other side of the Bosphorus regulated maritime traffic. A large chain might be strung between the two places to keep hostile Black Sea ships out.

Yoros Castle is located on the Anatolian side within the boundaries of the Beykoz district. Completed in 1262, Yoros Castle was in a very strategic position. With inscriptions from the Eastern Roman period on its walls, this castle remained under the control of the Genoese for a period.

places.name: Yoros Castle

reviews.text:
Add this to your trip! The fortress is neat but not extraordinary, but the view of Istanbul, the Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge, and of the Black Sea is quite astounding.

We had a car rental, so we drove from the airport and around the back side without any problems. Parking may be difficult, so you may need to park on the road and walk up. You can also visit via one of the cruises and hike up to the top from the village on the Bosphorus.

The castle itself has some great history worth reading about and learning. Some parts are in better repair than others. Be sure to go inside the main structure and admire the incredible brickwork and Ottoman architecture.

Take some time for some photos of the panoramic view, and take it all in. Listen for all the birds in this lush rural setting.

As for the castle, there's not much to see. You can see the remains of towers and fragments of walls. However, it's worth visiting for the incredible view. On one side, it overlooks the last bridge on the Bosphorus and the Black Sea, and on the other, Istanbul.

I came 35 years ago.
When I was at university
It's nice that It's still a virgin area üåø‚òòÔ∏èüå±üçÄüå≤üñºÔ∏è
Made some dirt around but
STILL ONE OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL VIEWS OF ISTANBUL . Those who want to visit Istanbul , should definitely go!
